conversation.content: [exhausted] They told me you've been down here for three days straight, working on the shield generators without any sleep or relief.
Seventy-two hours and counting, though time sort of loses meaning when you're this deep in the code. [weak laugh] The eastern perimeter breach wasn't your fault, you know.
[quietly] Twenty-seven people died while I was standing there with a useless sword, watching our defenses flicker and die like candles in the wind.
[barely audible] I keep seeing their faces every time I close my eyes, which is why I stopped closing them. The system cascade started in sector seven, not where you were stationed.
Doesn't matter. [sighs]
[wearily] You can't fight software bugs with steel, no matter how sharp your blade or how strong your armor might be.
And you can't debug code when your hands are shaking from exhaustion and your vision's going blurry from staring at screens. [softer] When did you last eat something?
[mumbling] There was a protein bar somewhere around hour forty-eight, maybe forty-nine, but honestly everything's starting to blend together now.
[gently] The shields can wait another hour while you eat the soup I brought down here, because we need you functional more than we need you martyred.
Every minute those shields stay down is another minute the city's vulnerable, and I'm so close to finding the root corruption that I can taste it. [exhales]
You know what I learned after fifteen years of combat? Dead heroes don't win wars, and exhausted technicians make mistakes that get more people killed.
[whispered] The code's degrading faster than I can patch it, like watching sand slip through my fingers no matter how tightly I try to hold on. [voice cracking]
[firmly gentle] Then let me hold the watch for one hour while you rest, because even machines need maintenance breaks.
[hollow laugh] You wouldn't know a recursive loop from a feedback cascade if it bit you on your armored backside, respectfully speaking.
No, but I know how to follow instructions, and you can walk me through keeping things stable while you close your eyes. [pause] Trust me.
[fading] The green lights need to stay green, the red ones are already lost causes, and if anything starts flashing yellow, wake me immediately.
[softly] I've stood vigil over dying comrades through longer nights than this, so watching lights while you sleep is the least I can do.
Promise me you won't try to fix anything yourself, because one wrong keystroke could cascade through the entire network. [drowsily] Just watch and wake me.
You have my word as a knight that I'll guard these systems like I'd guard your life, nothing more and nothing less.
Thank you. [whispered]

scenario: After a catastrophic system failure during a critical defensive operation, a battle-worn knight finds the technician who's been working for 72 hours straight trying to restore the shield generators.
